{{Infobox scholar | image = Ioan Kalinderu.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | name = Ioan Lazăr Kalinderu | fullname = | other_names = Ioan Calenderoglu, Iancu Kalinderu, Ioan Kelenderu, Ioanŭ Calenderu, Jean Kalindéro, Un Paysan du Danube | birth_date = {{birth date|1840|12|28}} | birth_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Wallachia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1913|12|11|1840|12|28}} | death_place = | school_tradition = [[Agrarianism]] | main_interests = {{hlist|[[jurisprudence]]|[[agricultural science]]|[[forestry]]|[[home economics]]|[[pedagogy]]|[[classical antiquity]]|[[legal history]]|[[social history]]}} | notable_ideas = | major_works = | influences = [[Spiru Haret]], [[Julius Kühn]] | influenced = | signature =I. Kalinderu sig (2).png }} '''Ioan Lazăr Kalinderu''' (born '''Calenderoglu''',<ref name="nimlr5">[[Nicolae Iorga]], "Molière și Romînii. Comunicație comemorativă la Academia Romînă", in ''Revista Istorică'', Nr. 1–3/1922, p. 5</ref> also known as '''Iancu Kalinderu''', '''Ioan Kelenderu''', '''Ioanŭ Calenderu''', or '''Jean Kalindéro''';<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', p. 793; Teodorescu ''et al'', pp. 849–853</ref> December 28 or 29, 1840 – December 11, 1913) was a [[Wallachia]]n, later [[Romania]]n jurist and confidant of [[King of the Romanians|King]] [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I]], who served for thirty years as the administrator of crown domains, and for three years as president of the [[Romanian Academy]]. Educated in France, he was the son of a rich and influential [[Greeks in Romania|Greek-Romanian]] banker, Lazăr Kalenderoglu, and the brother of physician [[Nicolae Kalinderu]]. Like them, he was a sympathizer of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]], with which he debuted in politics in the 1880s.
Kalideru was an expert in [[Roman law]], but his attempts in the field, as well as his later studies in the history of [[Ancient Rome]], are generally seen as minor contributions. His overall competence as an interpreter of law was questioned following his handling of the [[Strousberg Affair]], although he served on the [[High Court of Cassation and Justice|Court of Cassation]] and on international bodies of experts. Kalinderu stayed on as Carol's legal adviser, also helping him in direct negotiations with the National Liberal and [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative]] political machines, and was several times considered for the office of [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]].
As administrator for the crown, Kalinderu enacted his vision of rural improvement, setting up [[model farm]]s and a cottage industry, promoting literacy and the arts, and encouraging entrepreneurship. He viewed these methods as a working alternative to [[Land reform in Romania|land reform]], defending property rights during and after the [[1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt|peasants' revolt of 1907]]. He was praised for his passion and dedication, but also criticized for the uncertainty of their outcome. In addition to his agrarian project and his social work, Kalinderu played a significant part in promoting [[mountaineering]] and modern [[forestry]], set up the resort of [[Bușteni]], and created his own art museum. A picturesque figure with eccentric customs, and often regarded as snobbish and servile, he became a [[stock character]] for the writers and cartoonists at ''[[Furnica (magazine)|Furnica]]'' magazine. His unfulfilled promise to donate his fortune to the public bled into a posthumous scandal which lasted into the interwar years.
==Biography==
===Origins and early life=== Born in [[Bucharest]] on December 28 or 29, 1840,<ref name="aidi382">"Notices biographiques et bibliographiques sur les associés élus à Heidelberg", in ''Annuaire de l'Institut de Droit International'', 1888, p. 382</ref><ref name="sec">Corneliu Olaru, Vladimir Iovanov, ''Un secol de economie românească, 1848–1947'', p. 149. Bucharest: Editura NEWA T.E.D., 2001. {{ISBN|978-973-903-514-9}}</ref><ref name="amp100">{{ro icon}} Amuliu Proca, [http://www.agir.ro/univers-ingineresc/numar-1-2014/simpozionul-%E2%80%9Eacademicianul-ioan-kalinderu-administratorul-domeniilor-coroanei-la-100-de-ani-de-la-disparitie%E2%80%9C_4312.html "Simpozionul ''Academicianul Ioan Kalinderu, administratorul Domeniilor Coroanei, la 100 de ani de la dispariție''"], in ''Univers Ingineresc'', Nr. 1/2014</ref> his father was Lazăr (Lazaros) Kalenderoglu (or Calenderoglu). Of possible [[İzmir|Smyrniote]] origin,<ref name="muz">{{ro icon}} Simina Stan, [http://jurnalul.ro/timp-liber/casa/muzeul-kalinderu-o-restaurare-fara-sfarsit-530878.html "Muzeul Kalinderu, o restaurare fără sfărșit"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', December 19, 2009</ref> the family functioned as one of the largest banking and exporting institutions in Wallachia, and then in the [[United Principalities]].<ref>Zane, pp. 332, 377, 402</ref> Lazăr had risen into the ranks of Wallachia's [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar nobility]]: joining the Bucharest local government in 1838, 1844, and 1847, he was awarded the title of ''[[Pitar (rank)|pitar]]'',<ref>Lahovari ''et al.'', pp. 6–7. See also Gheorghe G. Bibescu, ''Domnia lui Bibescu. Tomul al doilea: Legi și decrete, 1843–1848; Răsvrătirea din 1848: istoria și legenda'', pp. 275–276. Bucharest: Typografia Curții Regale, F. Göbl Fii, 1894</ref> advancing to ''[[paharnic]]'' in the 1850s.<ref name="Ionașcu, p. 241">Ionașcu, p. 241</ref> His son would later falsely claim that the Kalenderoglus played a part in the [[Wallachian Revolution of 1848]],<ref name="m">[[Titu Maiorescu]] (ed. Stelian Neagoe), ''Istoria politică a României sub domnia lui Carol I'', p. 273. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 1994. {{ISBN|978-973-280-509-1}}</ref> although Lazăr is known to have held relevant positions in the [[National Party (Romania)|National Party]] in 1857, briefly serving as its chairman alongside [[Constantin A. Crețulescu]].<ref>Vasile Maciu, "Organizarea mișcarii pentru Unire în anii 1855–1857 în Moldova și Țara Românească", in ''Studii. Revistă de Istorie'', Nr. 1/1959, p. 69</ref> The last-ever tenant and tax collector of [[Predeal]] customs, Kalenderoglu had his estate in [[Olt County]], outside [[Colonești, Olt|Colonești]], reduced during the [[Land reform in Romania|land reform of 1864]].<ref>Lahovari ''et al.'', pp. 476, 565</ref> Another of his estates, at [[Nicolae Bălcescu, Vâlcea|Bălcești]], was repurchased by the Bălcescu boyars.<ref>Cornelia Bodea, Paul Cernovodeanu, Horia Nestorescu-Bălcești, ''Vatra Bălceștilor. Studii și documente'', p. 30. Bălcești pe Topolog: Nicolae Bălcescu Memorial Museum, 1971. {{OCLC|252339708}}</ref> However, he still left Ioan the manor of [[Schitu, Olt|Schitu-Greci]].<ref>Ionașcu, pp. 232, 240–242; {{ro icon}} Ion D. Tîlvănoiu, [http://www.memoriaoltului.ro/reviste/revista_47.pdf "Câteva date noi despre familia gazetarului N. T. Orășanu"], in ''Memoria Oltului și Romanaților'', Nr. 3/2015, p. 8</ref><ref name="cvfile39">{{ro icon}} Costel Vasilescu, [http://www.memoriaoltului.ro/reviste/revista_56.pdf "File din istoria răscoalei țărănești de la 1907"], in ''Memoria Oltului și Romanaților'', Nr. 11/2015, p. 39</ref>
Although a Wallachian native and relatively assimilated,<ref>Zane, p. 332. See also Bellessort, pp. 849, 852</ref> Lazăr was sometimes regarded as an [[Turks of Romania|ethnic Turk]], owing to his Turkish-sounding surname.<ref name="acarg56">Alinuța Cofan, "Pamfletul arghezian sau 'arta de a spurca frumos' (II)", in ''Caiete Critice'', Nr. 7/2013, p. 56</ref> He identified as [[Greeks in Romania|Greek-Romanian]] and, as late as 1879, was ''[[ktitor]]'' of an eponymous [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek Orthodox]] church in Bucharest. His fully assimilated son later barred the Greek colony from attending the church, and rededicated it to [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodoxy]].<ref>Cornelia Papacostea-Danielopolu, "La vie culturelle de la communauté grecque de Bucarest dans la seconde moitié du XIXe siècle", in ''Revue Des Études Sud-est Européennes'', Nr. 2/1969, pp. 318–319</ref> Ioan and his brother Nicolae were educated in Greek,<ref name="nimlr5"/> before graduating high school in Bucharest.<ref name="amp100"/> Ioan studied law at the [[University of Paris]]. Taking his license degree with a study of dowries in [[Roman law]] (1860), and earning a doctorate with a thesis on [[Ex post facto law|''ex post facto'' laws]] (''De la non-rétroactivité des lois'', 1864),<ref>Teodorescu ''et al'', pp. 849, 850–851</ref> he returned home to take up positions as a judge, serving as the first president of Bucharest Tribunal.<ref name="aidi382"/> He then became a counselor with the [[High Court of Cassation and Justice|Court of Cassation]].<ref name="aidi382"/><ref name="sec"/><ref name="amp100"/><ref name="tsctit">Tache Soroceanu, "Artistice. Muzeul Kalinderu: ctitorul și opera", in ''Ilustrațiunea Română'', Nr. 26/1934, p. 14</ref>
From 1872, the [[Ministry of Justice (Romania)|Ministry of Justice]] employed him as an adviser for penal reform, alongside [[Vasile Boerescu]], [[Nicolae Mandrea]], [[Grigore Păucescu]], [[Mihail Pherekyde]] and [[Grigore Triandafil]]. Boerescu referred to Kalinderu as "a man of the new world, with very progressive ideas, and an excellent jurisconsult."<ref>[[Vasile Boerescu]], ''Discursuri politice, 1859—1883. Volumul II: 1874—1883'', p. 110. Bucharest: [[Editura Socec|Atelierele Grafice Socec & Co.]], 1910</ref> At the time, his family was involved with the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|liberal-radical movement]]. Brother Nicolae, a Paris-trained physician, became one of the founders of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] in 1875.<ref>Bacalabașa I, pp. 146, 153, 171, 258</ref> The aged Kalenderoglu was founder of ''Creditul Rural'', a [[credit union]] for the benefit of peasants, alongside major liberal figures.<ref>Bacalabașa I, p. 115; Zane, p. 375</ref>
{{Gallery|align=right | title = | lines = 5 | width = 140 | height = 160 |File:Gheorghe Tattarescu - Portretul lui Lazar Kalinderu.jpg|Lazăr Kalenderoglu, by [[Gheorghe Tattarescu]] |File:Gheorghe Tattarescu - Sotia lui Lazar Kalinderu.jpg|Kalenderoglu's wife, also by Tattarescu }} In 1875, Ioan also joined the National Liberals in opposing the concession of the [[Căile Ferate Române Line 300|Predeal railway]] to the Englishman George Crawley; alongside party leaders [[Ion Brătianu]] and [[Dimitrie Sturdza]], he created an investment firm that tried to compete with Crawley for the contract.<ref>Bacalabașa I, pp. 168–169</ref> Kalinderu advanced on the public scene following the [[Strousberg Affair]], during which Romania purchased back her railways from the bankrupt [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussian]] investor [[Bethel Henry Strousberg|B. H. Strousberg]]. In February 1880, he and Strudza were dispatched to Berlin to negotiate payment of Strousberg's [[government bond]]s with the [[German Empire|Imperial German]] authorities.<ref>"Télégraphie privée (sérvice télégraphique de l'agence Havas)", in ''[[Journal des Débats]]'', February 29, 1880, p. 1</ref> In April, ''[[Domnitor]]'' [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I]] appointed him on the Princely Commission for the Administration of Railways, the embryonic ''[[Căile Ferate Române]]''. The other members of this directorial triumvirate were [[Eugeniu Stătescu]] and [[Ștefan Fălcoianu]].<ref>Constantin Gheorghe, Miliana Șerbu, ''Miniștrii de interne (1862–2007). Mică enciclopedie'', p. 95. Bucharest: [[Ministry of Administration and Interior (Romania)|Romanian Ministry of the Interior]], 2007. {{ISBN|978-973-745-048-7}}</ref> Kalinderu maintained his office in Berlin until 1882,<ref name="sec"/> representing the newly established [[Kingdom of Romania]]. In 1882, he published a French-language tome dealing specifically with the legal implications of the Strousberg Affair: ''De la compétence des tribunaux et particulièrernent des tribunaux prussiens dans toute contestation relative aux biens mobiliers qu'un état étranger peut posséder en Prusse''.<ref name="tt&al849">Teodorescu ''et al'', p. 849</ref>
As noted at the time by [[Titu Maiorescu]], Kalinderu was responsible for placing his government in a humiliating position, and it was surprising that such a mission was entrusted to so unqualified an individual.<ref name="m"/> Brătianu, who had taken over as [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]], arrived in Berlin to personally supervise the negotiations, reportedly because the hastiness on the German side to seal off the deal "inspired in him grave disquietude".<ref>''Documents diplomatiques français, 1871–1914. 1re série (1871–1900); Tome III (2 janvier 1880 – 13 mai 1881)'', p. 58. Paris: Alfred Costes & L'Europe Nouvelle, 1931</ref> According to one account, he viewed Kalinderu as incompetent, arranging for [[Eugeniu Carada]] to replace him as the actual negotiator, in all but name.<ref>Theodorian-Carada, pp. 86–88</ref> Nevertheless, Kalinderu's authority in international law was recognized following his employment by the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]].<ref name="amp100"/><ref name="fp77">Pădurean, p. 77</ref> From 1888, he was also an associate member of the [[Institut de Droit International]].<ref name="aidi382"/>
Kalinderu earned additional favors from Carol I, crowned [[King of the Romanians]], who appointed him his adviser on legal and agricultural matters.<ref name="amp100"/> For a while, he served as administrator of the state-owned forest and fields.<ref name="aidi382"/> In June 1884, Kalinderu was named the first administrator of crown domains, which had been set aside by organic law,<ref name="amp100"/><ref name="m"/><ref>Mihaesco, pp. 196–197</ref> resigning from his position at the railways company in December 1885.<ref>"Informațiuni", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', December 22, 1885, p. 3</ref> Owned by the state and managed by the [[House of Hohenzollern]] (through Kalinderu), the domains originally included twelve country estates and two mountains of the [[Southern Carpathians]]: [[Clăbucetul Taurului]] and [[Caraiman Peak|Caraiman]].<ref name="amp100"/> During the first years of his new assignment, Kalinderu tried to pursue a parallel career in politics. He ran for [[General Council of Bucharest|Bucharest Council]] in 1886, second on the National Liberal list.<ref>"Candidații Partidului național-liberal pentru alegerile comunale din Capitală", in ''[[Voința Națională]]'', November 2/14, 1886, p. 1</ref> He withdrew upon winning, citing his "many other engagements".<ref>"Ultime informațiunĭ", in ''[[Voința Națională]]'', November 6/18, 1886, p. 3</ref> During the [[Romanian general election, October 1888|election of 1888]], "I. Calenderoglu" ran at Olt as an independent, but lost, collecting 55 of 165 votes.<ref>"Resultatul alegerei Col. I", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', October 14/26, 1888, p. 1</ref> He eventually handled the purchase of Strousberg railways, negotiating a loan for 175 million [[Romanian leu|lei]] in 1889.<ref name="sec"/> In 1891, following the resignation of a [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]] government under [[Gheorghe Manu]], Carol reportedly proposed Kalinderu as Prime Minister of an independent cabinet. This maneuver was rejected by the opposition National Liberals—the refusal was instigated by a moribund Brătianu.<ref>Theodorian-Carada, pp. 106, 125</ref>
===Academy presidency=== By 1888, Kalinderu was elected a corresponding member of the [[Romanian Academy]].<ref name="aidi382"/> Made titular in March 1893, he became chairman of its Historical Section in 1895–1897, and again in 1907–1910.<ref name="fp77"/> He also served as Academy president from 1904 to 1907.<ref name="amp100"/><ref name="fp77"/> The administrator of the [[Ioan Oteteleșanu]] estate after winning the trial against his relatives in 1889,<ref name="Teodorescu et al, pp. 849, 850">Teodorescu ''et al'', pp. 849, 850</ref> he donated most of it to the Academy. The fund included 900 [[hectare]]s of land,<ref name="amp100"/> and ran at 4 million gold lei.<ref>Bacalbașa II, p. 152</ref> During his tenure there, Kalinderu marginalized [[Ioan Slavici]], who had criticized his management,<ref>[[Ovidiu Papadima]], "Ioan Slavici", in [[Șerban Cioculescu]], Ovidiu Papadima, [[Alexandru Piru]] (eds.), ''Istoria literaturii române. III: Epoca marilor clasici'', p. 390. Bucharest: [[Editura Academiei]], 1973</ref> and tried but failed to do the same with historian [[Radu Rosetti]].<ref>Rosetti, p. 189</ref> He was also confronted with criticism from [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]], who, in 1904, claimed that the Academy was turning into an "asylum for the intellectually impaired."<ref>Nastasă, pp. 497–498</ref>
Meanwhile, he continued to work as an envoy of the king. By 1899, with Romania hit by a major economic crisis, Kalinderu and Manu were sent abroad to negotiate loans—as Ornea notes, theirs was a "dilettante" adventure.<ref>[[Z. Ornea]], ''Junimea și junimismul'', Vol. I, pp. 350–352. Bucharest: [[Editura Minerva]], 1998. {{ISBN|973-21-0562-3}}</ref> Kalinderu also reported to his former Berlin colleague Sturdza, by then the National Liberal Prime Minister, that Carol had dismissed him,<ref>Theodorian-Carada, p. 136</ref> then negotiated a reunification of the Conservatives and ''[[Junimea]]'' defectors, prompted by the king's wish to have a stable government party.<ref>Marghiloman, p. 21</ref> He had declined offers to replace Sturdza himself, favoring [[Theodor Rosetti]] or [[Ioan Lahovary]] for that position.<ref>"Informații", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', July 21, 1898, p. 2</ref>
In 1896, Kalinderu restored the church on his own estate of Schitu-Greci, radically altering the overall design.<ref>Ionașcu, pp. 232, 241–242</ref> He was particularly concerned with building and restoring Orthodox religious buildings on the king's domain,<ref name="amp100"/><ref name="mr422">[[Marie of Romania]], ''Însemnări zilnice'', p. 422. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 2006. {{ISBN|978-973-876-888-8}}</ref><ref name="nm197">Mihaesco, p. 197</ref> personally involved in restoring and refurbishing the church of [[Periș|Bălteni-Periș]].<ref>"Donațiuni", in ''Biserica Orthodoxă Română. Revistă Periodică Eclesiastică'', Nr. 12, March 1900, p. 1191</ref> He supervised [[model farm]]s,<ref name="amp100"/><ref name="tsctit"/><ref>Mihaesco, p. 197; Mitu, pp. 304–305</ref> wrote a textbook for crown agents,<ref name="tt&al850">Teodorescu ''et al'', p. 850</ref> and ordered the founding of cultural societies, the first appearing on a domain in 1897.<ref name="mr422"/> It published the eponymous "people's encyclopedic magazine", ''Albina'' ("The Bee"), appearing between October 1897 and 1916. Kalinderu was the head editor, with [[George Coșbuc]], [[Petre Dulfu]], and [[Petre Vasiliu-Năsturel]] serving as co-editors.<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', pp. 14–15</ref> His work in public literacy also led him to establish Steaua Association. Joined by [[Constantin Banu]] and [[Spiru Haret]], and later by [[Barbu Știrbey]] and [[Alexandru Lapedatu]], it had as its object the promotion of "moral, patriotic and useful publications", and the prevention, "by all lawful meas, of immoral writings and publications".<ref>"«Steaua»", in ''Albina. Revistă Enciclopedică Populară'', Nr. 51/1901, p. 1976; "«Steaua»", in ''Albina. Revistă Enciclopedică Populară'', Nr. 22/1915, p. 839</ref>
Kalinderu was also editor of [[Ministry of Culture and National Patrimony (Romania)|Culture Ministry]]'s newsletter, ''Buletinul Comisiunii Monumentelor Istorice'', and of the forestry magazine, ''Revista Pădurilor'',<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', pp. 80, 550</ref> serving as chairman of the Historical Monuments Commission, the Progress in Forestry Society, and the Royal Geographical Society.<ref name="fp77"/> He was also offered chairmanship of the [[Romanian Atheneum]], but regretfully declined, arguing that he was caught up in his agricultural work. Instead, he promised to bequeath a "handsome sum" of money to the Atheneum upon his death.<ref name="ștci">Ștefan C. Ioan, "Amintiri din trecutul Ateneului Român", in ''Cele Trei Crișuri'', Nr. 3–4/1944, pp. 60–61</ref> In 1906, following Sturdza's second fall from office, Kalinderu was again tipped as the likely Prime Minister.<ref>C. Ulysse, "D. Sturdza la Rege. – Un guvern Kalinderu", in ''Protestarea'', March 8, 1906, p. 1</ref>
Described by [[Zigu Ornea]] as a "pseudo-historian", Kalinderu authored "risible" studies on Roman hairstyles,<ref name="z">[[Titu Maiorescu]] (ed. [[Z. Ornea]]), ''T. Maiorescu și prima generație de maiorescieni'', p. 348. Bucharest: [[Editura Minerva]], 1978</ref> which also drew much amusement from contemporaries.<ref>Gheorghe I. Bodea, ''Regele Carol al II-lea'', p. 48. Cluj-Napoca: [[Editura Dacia]], 2000. {{ISBN|978-973-350-925-7}}</ref> They were published in 1900–1901 as ''Portul barbeĭ și pĕruluĭ la Romanĭ'' ("Beard and Hair Styling among the Romans") and ''Portul perucilor și bărbieriĭ la Romanĭ'' ("Wigs and Barbers of the Romans").<ref name="tt&al850"/> Kalinderu's other publications have been characterized by Maiorescu as "compilations with no value".<ref name="m"/> They include monographs on the ''[[Praetor|praetorium ius]]'' (1885), on Roman municipal law and on the [[Byzantine Senate]] (both 1887), on the [[Twelve Tables]] (1888), on Roman vacationing (1895), on [[Augustus]] and his literary retinue (1897–1898), on [[Caesar's Civil War]] (1902), on [[clothing in ancient Rome]] (1903–1904), and on social life during the times of [[Pliny the Elder]] (1904).<ref>Teodorescu ''et al'', pp. 849–851</ref> He also published an homage to [[Stephen III of Moldavia|Stephen the Great]], medieval [[Prince of Moldavia]], studies of succession to the Romanian throne, and an Academy-sanctioned biography of [[Melchisedec Ștefănescu]].<ref>Teodorescu ''et al'', pp. 849, 850, 851</ref> In an 1888 polemical tract, ''Une poignée de vérités à nos prétendants'' ("A Fistful of Truths for Our Detractors"), Kalinderu and [[Alexandru Candiano-Popescu]], using the shared pseudonym ''Un Paysan du Danube'' ("A Peasant of the Danube"), defended their work alongside the king.<ref>Teodorescu ''et al'', p. 851</ref>
===Agrarian reformer=== Kalinderu largely owed his ascent into prominent positions to his work at the crown domains and his influence with Carol I.<ref name="z"/> However, his activity in agricultural and social improvement earned him respect. As early as 1898, [[Angelo de Gubernatis]] referred to his "powerful and positive work", calling Kalinderu "one of the most noble figures in today's Romania".<ref>[[Angelo de Gubernatis]], ''La Roumaine et les roumains. Impressions de voyage et études'', p. 21. Florence: Bernard Seeber libraire-éditeur, 1898</ref> Another visitor, [[André Bellessort]], joked that the perpetually youthful "Mr. Kalindero" resembled "a rustic god", a patron of the farmers with "nitrogen eyes".<ref>Bellessort, pp. 849–851</ref> Kalinderu's contributions to agricultural science and his activism, covered in a 1903 monograph by the agrarianist [[Vasile Kogălniceanu]],<ref>Teodorescu ''et al.'', p. 877</ref> were praised by the sociologists: [[Dimitrie Drăghicescu]] saw them as marked by an "entrepreneurial spirit, unrelenting in its activity";<ref>Drăghicescu, p. 559</ref> Nicolae Mihăescu-Nigrim called Kalinderu "one of the country's most eminent economists" and an "indefatigable administrator".<ref>Mihaesco, pp. 196, 201</ref> As chemist Amuliu Proca notes, Kalinderu turned the domains into an "institution for defeating poverty, a factor in educating and culturally improving the villages". It "set an example of what may be accomplished, in a short while, by a country that was taking major steps in her development."<ref name="amp100"/>
As summarized by the official press of his time, he "put all his efforts into directing peasants toward the cottage industry", created "home economics classes and adult education courses", and "was the first to speak" at educational conferences. He established a dairy factory, as well as shops for weavers, ropemakers, [[wainwright]]s and [[woodturner]]s, and showcased their products at the [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|1900 World's Fair]].<ref name="nm197"/> Following [[Julius Kühn]], Kalinderu insisted that the precondition of a "rational economy" was good livestock, so he inaugurated a freely accessible [[breeding program]], also providing tenants with [[cultivar]]s, or with beekeeping and [[sericulture]] implements.<ref>Mitu, pp. 309–311</ref> He also reintroduced [[reforestation]] and [[forest farming]] where bad practices had affected the environment.<ref>Mitu, pp. 310–311</ref> Kalinderu held the notion that the Romanian peasant was miserable for being illiterate, and that "all it takes is a set of favorable circumstances for him to display [his] talents".<ref>Drăghicescu, p. 528</ref> The efforts to educate his tenants were conjugated with those of ''Steaua''{{'}}s Haret, by then National Liberal [[Ministry of Education and Scientific Research (Romania)|Minister of Education]], providing young students with work experience and [[physical culture]], as well as inculcating in them a patriotic awareness.<ref>Mitu, pp. 311–312, 313–315</ref> A significant portion of his time was spent on teaching peasants to diversify their diet, including providing hired hands with daily rations of vegetables, meat and milk. This helped to prevent outbursts of [[pellagra]].<ref>Mitu, pp. 315–316</ref>
[[File:Ludovic Bassarab - In carciuma.jpg|thumb|330px|''In the Tavern'', 1907 painting by [[Ludovic Bassarab]]]] In 1901, agronomist [[Constantin Sandu-Aldea]] acknowledged that there was a stark difference between "the mass of cultivators, who fall behind progress", and those living and working on crown lands. As he noted, the "intelligent and energetic" Kalinderu was managing his estate and his tenants backed by "all scientific data in modern agriculture."<ref>[[Constantin Sandu-Aldea|C. Sandu]], "Les engagements agricoles en Roumanie", in ''Journal d'Agriculture Pratique, de Jardinage et d'Économie Domestique'', Vol. 65, 1901, p. 705</ref> Modeling his effort on the [[Austro-Hungarian rule in Bosnia and Herzegovina|Austrian colonization of Bosnia]], Kalinderu financed research projects for his employees, sending many of them to study in [[Austria-Hungary]].<ref>Mitu, pp. 312–313</ref> On crown estates, management was divided between networks of forestry engineers, agricultural engineers, and accountants, who decided working hours and met budgetary requirements; workers received social security, including [[disability insurance]].<ref>Mitu, pp. 303–306, 308–309</ref> These and other contracts excluded drunkards and unmarried couples, with a view to promoting a stringent moral code.<ref>Mitu, p. 315</ref> However, his attempts to uproot alcoholism and promote personal hygiene had mixed results, according to the left-wing [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], who noted, sarcastically, "true enough, these days taverns have been replaced by bathhouses and libraries."<ref name="fp84">Pădurean, p. 84</ref> Likewise, a 1901 project to set up rural theaters was derided and parodied by [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], in ''[[Moftul Român]]''.<ref name="fp84"/> Reportedly, his order to build model libraries on the domains was actively sabotaged by the local curators, who would not allow peasants to consult them, or even to set foot in the buildings.<ref>[[Al. Lascarov-Moldovanu]], ''Cruce și naționalism. Însemnările unui trecător'', pp. 72–73. Bucharest: [[Editura Cugetarea]], 1925</ref>
Kalinderu took over his father's seat at ''Creditul Rural'', which financed the cottage industry and, in 1906, was chaired by Sturdza. The institution was rocked by scandals between its Conservative and National Liberal managers—when Sturdza stepped down in March 1906, Kalinderu became his replacement.<ref>Bacalbașa III, p. 113</ref> His belief in self-help and his defense of landed-property rights against another land reform were highlighted after the [[1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt|peasants' revolt of 1907]], during which his own estate at Schitu-Greci was ransacked.<ref name="cvfile39"/> At the Progress in Forestry Society, he condemned the peasants' belief that "the state has a duty to provide them with land", and insisted that the root cause of the revolt was their failure to accept modernity and practicality. As he noted at the time, "on the crown domains, [...] the peasants never rebelled, but quite the contrary, defended property against invaders."<ref>"Dl Kalinderu despre starea țăranilor", in ''Tribuna'', Nr. 105/1907, p. 3</ref>
Mediating between the Conservatives and the king, Kalinderu obtained guarantees against the reform, although he and the crown advocated "a credit union under the control of the state, permitting peasants to accumulate more land of their own."<ref>Marghiloman, p. 63</ref> By then, he had resigned from his steering position at ''Creditul Rural'', following an agreement with [[Dinu Brătianu]], who replaced him.<ref>"Din România", in ''Tribuna'', Nr. 235/1907, p. 5</ref> In 1908–1911, his ''Albina'' team also put out a weekly "social bulletin", providing Orthodox parsons and rural teachers with guidance in the field social work.<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', p. 71</ref>
===Art collector and courtier=== Kalinderu's other ambitious ideas manifested themselves erratically, including a project for a girls' boarding school in [[Turnu Măgurele]], the "Oteteleșanu Institute",<ref>Pădurean, p. 85; Teodorescu ''et al'', p. 849</ref> which he launched without the Academy's approval.<ref name="m"/> He was also involved in the development of the [[Bușteni]] mountain resort, where he built a paper mill and a high school that today bears his name. He promoted ski, and a slope there is also named in his honor.<ref>{{ro icon}} Sorin Anghel, [http://jurnalul.ro/sport/sporturi/partia-kalinderu-asteapta-schiorii-32728.html "Pârtia Kalinderu așteaptă schiorii"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', November 24, 2005</ref> His own estate increased by 1907, with the addition of 401 hectares at [[Seaca, Teleorman|Seaca]]—leased out to the Predescu brothers—and other plots in [[Balaci|Tecuci-Kalinderu]].<ref>Steluța Chefani-Pătrașcu, ''Moșieri teleormăneni (1864–1949). Mărire și decădere (Publicațiile Muzeului Județean Teleorman, VI)'', pp. 283, 288, 294. Renaissance: Bucharest, 2011. {{ISBN|978-606-637-009-7}}</ref>
From July 1906 onward,<ref>"Din România. Știri dela expoziție", in ''Tribuna'', Nr. 132/1906, p. 2</ref> his other pet project was art collecting, with the goal of setting up a museum at his villa on Vasile Sion Street, near the [[Cișmigiu Gardens]]. The house itself, designed by [[Ion D. Berindey]], cost 2 million gold lei to build, and was lavishly furnished.<ref name="tsctit"/> The collection included [[Ancient Greek pottery]] and works of design alongside art by [[Donatello]], [[Andrea del Verrocchio]], [[Giovanni Paolo Panini]], [[Théodore Géricault]], [[Léon Bonnat]], [[Auguste Raffet]], and the complete collection of etchings by [[Giovanni Battista Piranesi|Piranesi]]. These were matched by a Romanian hall, with canvasses by [[Nicolae Grigorescu]], [[Ștefan Luchian]], [[Ion Andreescu]], [[Camil Ressu]] and various others.<ref name="tsctit"/>
The art world was skeptical of his tastes: [[Tudor Arghezi]] and [[Alexandru Lapedatu]] both noted that Kalinderu had amassed his ''[[Objets d'art|objets]]'' without much discernment; later, art historian Petre Oprea concluded that Kalinderu was driven by "vainglory and a thirst for fame."<ref>Pădurean, pp. 81–82</ref> Similarly, critic [[George Oprescu]] suggests that Ioan's taste in art was eclipsed by that of his physician brother Nicolae, who selected "all that is best" in the Kalinderu collection.<ref>[[George Oprescu]], "Colecția de tablouri a Clubului Tinerimii", in ''Boabe de Grâu'', Nr. 2/1934, pp. 75–77</ref> According to the fellow collector [[Krikor Zambaccian]]: "dapper, distant and implacable, the Smyrniote was haughty and did not tolerate competition".<ref name="muz"/> Zambaccian found his rival overall "harmless", even though he noted an incident in which an angry Kalinderu "decapitated" a work of sculpture.<ref>Pădurean, pp. 82–83</ref>
Kalideru's other eccentricities attracted attention in their own right. Seen by contemporaries and later historians as excessively vain and hence susceptible, he was decorated with the ribbons of numerous European countries,<ref name="m"/><ref name="fp78">Pădurean, p. 78</ref> holding the Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Star of Romania]], the [[Legion of Honour]] as Grand Officer,<ref name="Teodorescu et al, pp. 849, 850"/> and, from 1903, the Grand Cordon of the [[Order of Osmanieh]].<ref>[[Pierre Quillard]], "Nouvelles d'Orient. Condamnations et décorations", in ''Pro Armenia'', No. 65, July 15, 1903, p. 327</ref> In one of his charges, Arghezi claimed that Kalinderu, the "Man with Violet Eyes", was entirely alien to the nation he claimed to rescue, a "purulent flower on the heights of our national life."<ref name="acarg56"/> Lapedatu commented on his "wicked half-closed Oriental eyes", his "black mustache like that of [[Napoleon III]]", and his dress "in the English style, with wide pants, gray jacket, an enormous lapel flower and a tall gray hat".<ref name="muz"/> [[Constantin Argetoianu]] observed that although Kalinderu lacked all inclination toward sport or riding, he would go out every morning on a nag he could barely ride.<ref name="muz"/><ref name="fp79">Pădurean, p. 79</ref> Although this activity bored him, he would not have renounced it for anything, because he had read it was a habit of lords in London.<ref name="muz"/> Later, he became an ardent [[Velocipede|velocipedist]], and was the only person with special permission to ride a velocipede in Cișmigiu.<ref name="muz"/><ref name="fp79"/>
As seen by [[Radu R. Rosetti]], Kalinderu appears "sententious, ridiculous, but very much appreciated by the King".<ref>Rosetti, p. 126</ref> Reportedly, he worked for free at the crown domains, refusing to collect his salary: "The only rewards he desires are peasant blessings and his playing billiards with His Majesty."<ref>Bellessort, p. 851</ref> The king's appreciation was strictly contextual, a fact noticed by the politician [[Ion G. Duca]]: although Kalideru "entertained illusions" that he was personal friends with Carol, the latter "made sure to dispel it"; the courtier could be the king's "servant and useful instrument, but never his friend."<ref>Duca, p. 102</ref> Reportedly, Carol also ordered Kalinderu to admonish [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Crown Prince Ferdinand]] and [[Marie of Romania|Princess Marie]] for their lavish spending.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Bulei]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/acum-un-veac-xlii-talentele-mariei-ii-de-ion-bulei-14957096 "Acum un veac (XLII). Talentele Mariei (II)"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', January 7, 2016</ref> The future Queen Marie was much amused by Kalinderu, describing him as "little, round, with a short beard and a pronounced [[Jewish nose|Semitic nose]]; one of his eyes sparkled wickedly, showing an unusually sharp intelligence".<ref name="fp77"/><ref name="mrgent">{{ro icon}} [http://jurnalul.ro/special-jurnalul/reportaje/maria-regina-romaniei-un-gentilom-in-care-regele-carol-avea-cea-mai-mare-incredere-644483.html "Maria Regina României. Un gentilom în care regele Carol avea cea mai mare încredere"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', June 1, 2013</ref> She recalled a visit with him to [[Windsor Castle]], where "it was truly amusing to see the short gentleman very pleased with himself, catching everything with his glimpse, weighing, judging, taking the measure of people and things, with that small, penetrating, almost wicked eye". Even when meeting [[Queen Victoria]], his eye "roved throughout, as if he feared missing something".<ref name="mrgent"/> When he was shown [[Royal Collection|the castle's art treasures]], he observed them "with the superior air of a man in the know, of a man who was familiar with valuable collections".<ref name="mrgent"/><ref>Pădurean, p. 83</ref>
===Final years, death, and legacy=== As noted by the queen, Kalinderu's "vain, self-satisfied appearance" became "a tireless temptation for caricaturists".<ref name="fp77"/><ref name="mrgent"/> During the nine years in which their activity overlapped, the magazine ''[[Furnica (magazine)|Furnica]]'' made him a buffoonish [[stock character]] in prose, poetry, and cartoons.<ref>Pădurean, pp. 79–81</ref> ''Furnica''{{'}}s [[George Ranetti]] also circulated serious charges against Kalinderu, accusing him of having run over a child with his car, and implying that he had used his connections to avoid prosecution.<ref>[[George Ranetti|Kiriak Napadarjan]], "Gardiștii și ''Furnica''", in ''[[Furnica (magazine)|Furnica]]'', Nr. 196/1908, p. 5</ref> During the peasants' revolt, ''Furnica'' published a cartoon showing Kalinderu as a personification of Cajolery, interposing himself between Carol and The Truth (personified by a tenant farmer);<ref>Rosetti, p. 90</ref> issues of that period were confiscated by the [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Romania)|Ministry of Internal Affairs]].<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', p. 269</ref> Reportedly, Kalinderu himself was generally aware of the mockery, but pretended to be "inviolable",<ref name="fp78"/> and even incited Ranetti by riding his horse to his office.<ref name="tsctit"/> However, ''Furnica'' gleefully reported, he lost his temper with the painter [[Ion Theodorescu-Sion]], who had contributed a set of cartoons to the campaign. According to the magazine, this incident showed his limitations as an art patron.<ref>Pădurean, pp. 80–81</ref> {{Gallery|align=center | title = | lines = 5 | width = 150 | height = 160 |File:Witold Rolla-Piekarski - Zarzavat regal, Furnica, 4 dec 1908.JPG|Carol I and Kalinderu as gardeners, reaping the vegetable-politicians; by [[Witold Rolla-Piekarski]] |File:NSPetrescuGaina - Conu Iancu Kalinderu.jpg|Kalinderu the horseman, by [[Nicolae Petrescu-Găină]] |File:NSPetrescuGaina - Iancu Kalideru.jpg|Kalinderu the velocipedist, also by Petrescu-Găină |File:Ion Theodorescu-Sion - Muzăul lui Conu Iancu, Furnica 18 feb 1910.png|Kalinderu as an art collector, with [[Maica Smara]]; by [[Ion Theodorescu-Sion]] }} Among Kalinderu's late contributions as a philanthropist was his involvement with the [[Romanian Red Cross]]. From October 1912, he served on its general council, alongside Sturdza, [[Gheorghe Grigore Cantacuzino]], [[Grigore C. Crăiniceanu]], [[Nicolae Filipescu]], and [[Alexandru Obregia]].<ref>"Parte neoficială. Anunțuri administrative", in ''[[Monitorul Oficial]]'', Nr. 184/1912, p. 8685</ref> He spent the better part of 1913 in conflict with the Conservative government, headed by his old rival Maiorescu. Against Maiorescu, Kalinderu tried to persuade Carol not to renew the pact tying Romania to the [[Triple Alliance (1882)|Triple Alliance]]. Arguing that it constituted support for a [[Mitteleuropa|German hegemony]], he managed to postpone its ratification.<ref>[[Nicolae Iorga]], ''Memorii. Vol. III: Tristețea și sfârșitul unei domnii'', p. 184. Bucharest: [[Editura Națională Ciornei]], 1931. {{OCLC|5673988}}</ref> One of his final gestures was the intervention in favor of a protegé scholar, [[Orest Tafrali]], for whom he obtained a chair at [[Iași University]].<ref>Nastasă, pp. 340, 518</ref> He also made returns to scholarship, publishing in 1912 a commentary on the influence of [[Byzantine art]] on Romanian visual culture. It built on observations made by [[Gabriel Millet]].<ref>Em. E. Kretzulescu, "Dări de seamă. I. Kalinderu, ''Notă despre un studiu al d-lui Millet''", in ''Revista pentru Istorie, Archeologie și Filologie'', Vol. XIII, Parts I–II, 1912, pp. 385–387</ref>
Kalinderu died in December 1913, and was buried at [[Bellu cemetery]], Plot 5, next to his father and his brother.<ref>Gheorghe G. Bezviconi, ''Necropola Capitalei'', p. 80. Bucharest: [[Nicolae Iorga Institute of History]], 1972</ref> The funeral witnessed speeches by [[Constantin C. Arion]], [[Constantin Istrati]], [[Basile M. Missir]], and [[Sabba Ștefănescu]].<ref name="tt&al849"/> Kalinderu intended to disinherit his relatives and see his name praised after giving lavish donations to royal and academic institutions of culture; however, none of the wills were written in legal form, so that Kalinderu's wealth largely ended up going to his relatives.<ref name="m"/><ref name="ștci"/><ref>Pădurean, pp. 83–84, 84–85</ref> The mystery and scandal surrounding Kalinderu's last wish inspired a novella by [[Nicolae M. Condiescu]]. This fictionalizes one theory, according to which Kalinderu ("Conu Enake" in the story) writes down a will donating his fortune to the Academy, then destroys it on a whim.<ref>Pădurean, p. 85</ref>
From 1914, Kalideru's job at the crown domains went to [[Barbu Știrbey]].<ref>Duca, p. 125; Mitu, p. 303</ref> A museum bearing Ioan and Nicolae's names, containing their respective art collections, opened the same year. The first private art museum in the country,<ref name="amp100"/> it suffered damages [[Romania in World War I|during World War I]]: its Romanian-art section was evacuated during the [[battle of Bucharest]], then confiscated by [[Bolshevik Russia]].<ref name="tsctit"/> Kalinderu's park at Schitu-Greci was vandalized during the war and, by 1934, had still not been repaired.<ref name="Ionașcu, p. 241"/>
Reopened during the interwar with the remainder of its collection,<ref name="tsctit"/> the Kalinderu museum had [[Jean Alexandru Steriadi]] as its last director.<ref>[[Adrian Cioroianu]], ''Pe umerii lui Marx. O introducere în istoria comunismului românesc'', p. 138. Bucharest: [[Editura Curtea Veche]], 2005. {{ISBN|973-669-175-6}}</ref> It was eventually closed in 1946,<ref name="muz"/><ref name="dtcenu">{{ro icon}} Doinel Tronaru, [http://www.romanialibera.ro/actualitate/fapt-divers/muzeul-kalinderu-va-renaste-din-propria-i-cenusa--60300 "Muzeul Kalinderu va renaște din propria-i cenușă"], in ''[[România Liberă]]'', September 23, 2005</ref> shortly before the inauguration of a [[Communist Romania|Romanian communist regime]]. Following the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], Kalinderu's work and legacy were revisited: in 2005, a project to reestablish Kalinderu Museum was being debated.<ref name="muz"/><ref name="dtcenu"/> In January 2014, the centennial of Kalinderu's death was solemnly marked by the General Association of Romanian Engineers, which discussed opening up a museum of the crown domains in [[Segarcea]].<ref name="amp100"/>

[[Norwegian Critics Prize for Literature]] }} '''Johannes Gjerdåker''' (born 15 February 1936) is a Norwegian local historian, poet, translator, non-fiction writer and publisher. Gjerdåker was born in [[Voss]], and studied history and language at the [[University of Oslo]]. He made his literary debut in 1978 with the poetry collection ''Skot på gamal stuv''. He has written several works on local history of Voss and [[Hordaland]]. In 1992 he was awarded the cultural prize from the municipality of Voss. He received the [[Bastian Prize]] in 1997 and the [[Melsom Prize]] in 1999, both for translation of works by [[Robert Burns]] into [[Nynorsk]]. In 2005 he received the [[Norwegian Critics Prize for Literature|Critics Prize for the year's best work of translation]], for translation of works by [[Horace]].{{cite encyclopedia|title=Johannes Gjerdåker |first=Eivind |last=Myklebust |editor-first=Ottar |editor-last=Grepstad |editor-link=Ottar Grepstad |encyclopedia=Allkunne |publisher=Nynorsk kultursentrum |location= |url=https://www.allkunne.no/framside/biografiar/g/johannes-gjerdaker/90/83900/ |language=Norwegian|accessdate=19 March 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gjerdaker, Johannes}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Voss]] [[Category:University of Oslo alumni]] [[Category:Norwegian historians]] [[Category:Norwegian translators]] [[Category:Norwegian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:20th-century Norwegian poets]] [[Category:Nynorsk-language writers]] [[Category:Norwegian male poets]] [[Category:20th-century Norwegian male writers]] {{Norway-writer-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=August 2011}} '''Julián Juderías y Loyot''' (September 16, 1877 – June 19, 1918) was a Spanish [[historian]], [[sociologist]], literary critic, [[journalist]], [[translator]] and [[interpreter]].
== Biography == [[File:J.Juderías Unterschrift.jpg|thumb|Signature of Julian Juderías]] Juderías was born in [[Madrid]] to a prominent an cultured family. His father, [[Mariano Juderías]], was a well-known historical author and translator. His mother was French. At 17, he began work with the Spanish Ministry of State. In 1900, after the death of his father, he moved to [[Paris]] to attend the School of Eastern Languages. There and in [[Leipzig]] and [[Odessa|Odesa]] he studied [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Russian language|Russian]] and other languages. His main work was a study about the [[Black Legend]], in which he denounced the tendentious, nonobjective historical writing or propaganda about [[Spain]], its people and its culture.
Years after his death, Juderías' works greatly influenced conservative thinkers such as [[Ramiro de Maeztu]] and [[José María de Areilza]].

'''Landulf of Saint Paul''' ([[floruit]] 1077–1137), called '''Landulf Junior''' to distinguish him from [[Landulf Senior]],<ref>His name in Italian is ''Landolfo di San Paolo'' or ''Landolfo Iuniore''; in Latin ''Landulphus Iunior''.</ref> was a [[Milan]]ese historian whose life is known entirely from his main work, the '''''Historia Mediolanensis'''''. He presents a unique and important point of view from the conflict-ridden years of 1097–1137 in Milan. He thrice sojourned in [[Kingdom of France|France]] while his ecclesiastical faction—the [[Pataria]]—was out of favour in Milan, and there learned under some of the leading philosophers of western Europe. After 1113, Landulf's primary ambition was to regain the priesthood in the church of San Paolo which he had lost, and to this end he communicated with popes and emperors. He played a role—large in his own account—in the election of [[Conrad III of Germany|Conrad of Hohenstaufen]] as [[King of Italy]] in 1128.
==Life==
===Travels in France=== Landulf's birth year can be approximated from his statement that he was "sixty years old" (''sexagenariae aetatis'') in 1136.<ref name=Chiesa>Chiesa (2004).</ref> He was a nephew and student of [[Liprando]], a Milanese priest and one of the leaders of the [[Pataria]] in the last quarter of the eleventh century. Towards the end of the century, Landulf became an [[acolyte]] (''acolitus''), which was recognised as the highest-ranking of the [[minor orders]] in Milan at the time. He held this rank for the rest of his life.<ref name=Chiesa/> In 1095–96, Landulf studied under master Andrea Dalvolto, a priest of the church of San Tecla. Among his fellow students was Nazario Muricola, later his enemy.<ref name=Chiesa/> Later, probably in 1102, he went to [[Orléans]] to study under the masters Alfred and James. He may have been avoiding the conflict between the Patarenes, led by Liprando, and the new Papally-approved archbishop, [[Grosolanus]]. He was absent from Milan in 1103, when his uncle passed a [[trial by ordeal]].<ref name=Chiesa/>
Landulf returned to Milan, but left for France again in 1106. There he stayed for a year and a half with the prominent reforming Milanese churchmen [[Anselmo della Pusterla]] and [[Olrico da Corte]], perhaps acting as their secretary. In [[Tours]] he sat under the teaching of a master Alfred, perhaps the same one that had taught him half a decade earlier in Orléans, and in [[Paris]] he received lessons from the philosopher [[William of Champeaux]].<ref name=Chiesa/> In 1107, Landulf returned again to Milan and escorted his uncle back from exile at [[Civate]].
In 1109, Landulf's brother Antelmo died in the war between Milan and [[Lodi, Lombardy|Lodi]], and Landulf again went to France with Anselmo della Pusterla and Olrico da Corte. This time he stayed in [[Laon]] and learned under [[Anselm of Laon|Anselm]] and his brother Ralph. This is the first trip abroad which Landulf characterises as an exile in his ''Historia'', noting that the city magistrate suggested their long absence in order to keep the peace between factions.<ref name=Chiesa/>
===Marginalisation in Milan=== Landulf returned to Milan in 1110. He looked favourably upon the entry of the [[Emperor Henry V]] into Italy in 1111. That year he fell out with Olrico da Corte upon the latter's abandonment of the Patarene position when he was made an [[archpresbyter]].<ref name=Chiesa/> In 1112–13 Landulf served in his uncle's former church of San Paolo in Compito, since lost, but remembered in the street named Via San Paolo. With his uncle, he founded a church dedicated to the [[Trinity]] at an unidentified place called "Pons Guinizeli".<ref name=Chiesa/> With Liprando and Andrea, ''[[primicerius]]'' and head of the ''[[decumani]]'', Landulf also opposed the election of [[Jordan (archbishop of Milan)|Jordan]] as archbishop in early 1112. When Jordan offered to make Landulf a subdeacon and cancel one of his debts in return for recognition of his legitimacy from the Pataria, Landulf refused.<ref name=Chiesa/>
With death of Liprando in January 1113 and of Andrea shortly after, Landulf found himself marginalised. He was expelled from San Paolo and from the ranks of the ''decumani'' by Andrea's successor, Nazario Muricola. Thus forced to seek an income outside of the church, he became a teacher and scribe, even working for the municipal government as a "holder of public offices and notary of consular letters" (''publicorum officiorum particeps et consulum epistolarum dictator'').<ref name=Chiesa/> This is the earliest reference to [[consul]]s in medieval Milan.<ref name=Chiesa/>
For the rest of his life Landulf tried to recover his office in San Paolo. According to him, Jordan made vague promises to get his support at the [[Lateran council of 1116]], but reneged at an assembly (''[[arengo]]'') in 1117. Landulf obtained a letter of recommendation from [[Pope Gelasius II]], which Jordan ignored, in 1118. He went to Rome to plead his case to [[Pope Callistus II]] in 1120, but the pope did not intervene.<ref name=Chiesa/> Only with the death of Jordan in October and his replacement by Olrico, Landulf's former companion, did the latter achieve some redress—he returned to the ''decumani'', but was not reinstated in San Paolo. He attempted again to plead with Pope Callistus at the [[First Lateran Council|Lateran council of 1123–24]], but could not get an audience. In 1125 he joined a Milanese embassy to [[Kingdom of Germany|Germany]], hoping to plead his case to Emperor Henry, but the mission was cut short by the latter's death and never got further than [[Trento|Trent]].<ref name=Chiesa/>
===Return to power=== In 1126, Olrico was succeeded as archbishop by Anselmo della Pusterla. Landulf's former travelling companion appointed him head of the archiepiscopal chapel, in which capacity he served as a secretary and counsellor. In 1127 [[Conrad III of Germany|Conrad of Hohenstaufen]] was elected king in Germany in opposition to the emperor-elect [[Lothair of Supplinburg]]. Archbishop Anselm charged Landulf with ascertaining whether the Milanese would support Conrad or Lothair, while he himself left the city. Landulf afterwards claimed an important role in the choice of Conrad, who was crowned by Anselmo as [[King of Italy]] in 1128, first at [[Monza]], where the [[Iron Crown of Lombardy|Iron Crown]] was kept, then at Milan.<ref name=Chiesa/> In 1130, when Anselmo gave his support to the [[Antipope Anacletus II]], Landulf followed him. In 1135, he was convinced by [[Bernard of Clairvaux]] to support [[Pope Innocent II]], but when Anselmo was deposed and fled the city, Landulf was again pushed to the margins by a new archbishop, [[Robaldo di Alba]].<ref name=Chiesa/>
In November 1136, Landulf renewed his claim on the church of San Paolo before Lothair of Supplinburg, now undisputed emperor, who was holding court at [[Piacenza|Roncaglia]]. The emperor refused to adjudicate the dispute, leaving it to the local authorities. According to Landulf, the machinations of Arnaldo di Rho, chief of a clan traditionally opposed to the Pataria, succeeding in blocking his ambitions once more.<ref name=Chiesa/> This is the last notice of Landulf's life. He was still alive in the summer of 1137: he records the [[Battle of Genivolta]], a victory for Milan over [[Cremona]] early that year, and the flight of Bishop [[Oberto di Dovara]] of Cremona, who wound up a prisoner of the Milanese, some months later.<ref name=Chiesa/>
==''Historia Mediolanensis''== The title ''Historia Mediolanensis'', meaning "A Milanese History", is not contemporary. It was used as a source by several later medieval historians: [[Bonvesin da La Riva]], [[Goffredo da Bussero]], [[Benzo d'Alessandria]] and perhaps [[Galvano Fiamma]]. Nevertheless, it survives in only one manuscript tradition, at the font of which stands the fifteenth-century manuscript H.89.inf. in the [[Biblioteca Ambrosiana]] in Milan. Also at the Ambrosiana are N.296 sup., R.119 sup. and Trotti, 168; at the [[Biblioteca Trivulziana]], also in Milan, is manuscript 348. All these are copies of H.89.inf., a low-quality manuscript littered with errors and gaps.<ref name=Chiesa/> The codex contains, besides the ''Historia'' of Landulf Junior, several other histories of Milan: the ''Historia'' of Landulf Senior, the ''Liber gestorum recentium'' of [[Arnulf of Milan]] and a ''Passio'' on the death of [[Arialdo]] in 1066, once though to have been by Landulf Junior. In the manuscript the ''Historia'' is titled "The Book of the Histories of the Milanese City by Landulf of St Paul" (''Liber hystoriarum Mediolanensis urbis Landulfi de S. Paulo''). Medieval writers referred to it as the ''Copia Landulfi'' ("Landulf's Store"), probably based on the last line of the manuscript, ''in hac mea copia''. The term was sometimes applied to Arnulf's ''Liber gestorum recentium'' and the term ''Copia Arnulfi'' was sometimes applied to Landulf's ''Historia'', suggesting perhaps that the four works of Milanese history were treated as a single collection.<ref name=Chiesa/>
Landulf's ''Historia'' begins with the disputed election of [[Anselmo da Bovisio]] to the see of Milan in 1097. The narrative, which coincides with Landulf's adult life, is compact and circular. It begins with the unjust intervention of a Papal officer, [[Ermanno da Gavardo|Hermann]], in the affairs of the church of Milan and ends with the restoration of good relations between Milan and the Papacy by Bernard of Clairvaux. Landulf places the blame for the Milan's problems on Hermann, and notes with satisfaction that both Archbishops [[Anselm III (archbishop of Milan)|Anselmo III]] and [[Arnulf III (archbishop of Milan)|Arnulf III]] refusd to consecrate him after his election as [[bishop of Brescia]]. He also approves of King [[Conrad II of Italy|Conrad II]]'s refusal to have anything to do with Anselmo da Bovisio or Hermann's consecration.<ref>Cowdrey (1968), 292–94.</ref>
Although Landulf is a partisan narrator and his account judgemental as well as personal, it is historically valuable for its eyewitness testimony and its uncritical attitude.<ref name=Chiesa/> Landulf writes "without thorough understanding and remain[s] disturbed by the progressive breaking apart of the traditional order" that birthed the Milanese ''[[Medieval commune|comune]]''.<ref>Chiesa (2004): ''senza comprenderlo fino in fondo e rimanendo anzi turbato dalla progressiva frantumazione dell'ordine tradizionale''</ref> The quality of Landulf's writing is unexepectedly poor for one who received an education from the leading philosophers of France.
The ''Historia'' received its ''[[editio princeps]]'' from G. A. Sassi, on behalf of [[Ludovico Muratori]], in 1724. The standard [[critical edition]] is that of [[Ludwig Bethmann]] and [[Philipp Jaffé]] for the ''[[Monumenta Germaniae Historica]]'' in 1868.<ref name=Chiesa/>

{{italic title}} The '''''Lexicon Topographicum Urbis Romae''''' (1993‑2000) is a six-volume, multilingual reference work considered to be the major, modern work covering the [[topography of ancient Rome]].<ref name="Steinby1993">{{cite book|author=Eva Margareta Steinby|title=Lexicon Topographicum Urbis Romae: Volume Primo: A-C|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bIXrAAAAMAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Quasar|isbn=978-88-7097-019-7}}</ref> The editor is [[Margareta Steinby|Eva Margareta Steinby]], and the publisher is Edizioni Quasar of Rome. It is considered the successor to Platner and Ashby's ''[[A Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome]]''.
An ongoing series of supplements provides additional coverage of Roman topography and important topics in the archaeology of the city.

{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = | name = Lilian (Anne) Hamilton Jeffrey | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|01|05}} | birth_place = [[Westcliff-on-Sea]], United Kingdom | death_date = {{death date and age|1986|09|29|1915|01|05}} | death_place = | death_cause = | region = | nationality = | period = | occupation = | title = | boards = | known_for = | spouse = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | era = | language = | discipline = [[Classics]] | sub_discipline = [[Greek Epigraphy]] | movement = | religion = | denomination = | education = | alma_mater = [[Newnham College, Cambridge]]
[[University of Oxford]] (DPhil, 1951) | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | school_tradition = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | main_interests = | workplaces = [[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford]] | notable_works = The Local Scripts of Archaic Greece | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = | awards = Fellow of the British Academy, 1965 | website = | footnotes = }} '''Lilian Hamilton Jeffery''' (5 January 1915 – 29 September 1986) was a British archaeologist, classical philologist and epigraphist best remembered for her 1961 work ''The Local Scripts of Archaic Greece''. Building on the work of [[Adolf Kirchhoff]] and [[Antony E. Raubitschek]], Jeffery surveyed the development of the Greek alphabet from its adoption down to the fifth century BC and in so doing established the chronology of archaic inscriptions. ==Early life== Lilian (Anne) Jeffery was born at [[Westcliff-on-Sea]] to, Thomas Theophilus Jeffery, a schoolmaster and lecturer in Classics, and Lilian Mary Hamilton.{{Cite web|url=http://poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk/memoire/LHJ.memoire.01.html|title=Epigraphic Sources for Early Greek Writing|website=poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk|access-date=2018-02-05}} She was educated at [[Cheltenham Ladies' College]] and in 1933 won a Major Classical scholarship to [[Newnham College, Cambridge]] where she studied under [[Jocelyn Toynbee]].{{Cite web|url=http://poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk/memoire/LHJ.memoire.02.html|title=Epigraphic Sources for Early Greek Writing|website=poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk|access-date=2018-02-05}} ==Career== She won the Walton Studenship to the [[British School at Athens]] in 1937, where she contributed to the work of [[Antony E. Raubitschek]] on the sculptural fragments of the Acropolis, co-publishing with him the 1949 book ''Dedications from the Athenian Akropolis''.{{cite web|url=http://epigraphy.packhum.org/book/434?location=1360|title=Dedications from the Athenian Akropolis}} She served in the [[Women's Auxiliary Air Force|WAAF]] during [[World War II]]; part of her duties included intelligence interpretation of aerial photographs.{{Cite web|url=http://poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk/memoire/LHJ.memoire.04.html|title=Epigraphic Sources for Early Greek Writing|website=poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk|access-date=2018-02-05}} In 1946 she took up the position of research fellow at [[Lady Margaret Hall]], Oxford, where she remained for the rest of her career apart from a period of research at the Institute of Advanced Studies at Princeton from September 1951 to June 1952.{{cite web|url=https://www.ias.edu/scholars/lilian-hamilton-jeffery|title=Lilian Hamilton Jeffrey on the IAS website}} Her archaeological work included field study with the British School at Old Smyrna (Bayrakli) in 1949. She also made major contributions to the study of Attic grave monumentsPublished in BSA, lvii (1962), 115-53. and the epigraphical edition project ''[[Inscriptiones Graecae]]'' i3.IG i3 fasc. 2, with Jeffery's major contribution, was completed and published shortly before D.M. Lewis's death in 1994. From 1955 until 1961 she was an editor of the ''Annual of the British School at Athens.''{{Cite web|url=http://poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk/memoire/LHJ.memoire.05.html|title=Epigraphic Sources for Early Greek Writing|website=poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk|access-date=2018-02-05}} She was made a [[Fellow of the British Academy]] in 1965.{{Cite journal|last=Lewis|first=David|date=1987|title=Lilian Hamilton Jeffrey, 1915-1986|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/pubs/proc/files/73p505.pdf|journal=Proceedings of the British Academy|volume=73|pages=|via=}} Her archive is preserved at the Centre for the Study of Ancient Documents, Oxford, digitised and published online.{{cite web|url=http://poinikastas.csad.ox.ac.uk/introduction.shtml|title=The Anne Jeffery Archive}} ==Selected works== *ed. with Antony E. Raubitschek, ''Dedications from the Athenian Akropolis: A catalogue of the inscriptions of the 6. and 5. centuries B. C''. {{Cleanup|reason=large portions of text in this article are ungrammatical and/or barely intelligible|date=May 2016}} [[Image:Yoruba-bronze-head.jpg|thumb|[[Yoruba culture|Yoruba]] Ife bronze casting of a King, Nigeria c. 1300]] [[File:Ife Kings Head.jpg|thumb|Ife bronze casting of a King, dated around twelfth century]] [[File:Drummers at Ooni's Palace.jpg|thumb|Drummers at Ooni's Palace]] The '''Ooni of Ile-Ife''' ('''Ọọ̀ni''' of '''Ilè-Ifẹ̀''') is the traditional ruler of [[Ile-Ife]]. This Nigerian town is seen as the cradle of the Yoruba people. The Ooni dynasties go back hundreds of years. Because the oral tradition was only recently transcribed, there are several detailed lists that contradict each other. Nevertheless, some key figures are common to all of them. All the Ooni are traced down to Oduduwa, who is seen as the ancestral father of all the Yoruba people. Ooni Oranmiyan, who is said to have lived between 1200 and 1300 A.D, became legendary{{cite book|chapter=25: the staff of Oranyan|title= Yoruba Legends|author=M. I. Ogumefu, B.A. | year=1929| publisher=london| url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/afr/yl/yl27.htm}} for his role in creating many new towns. One of his sons, Eweka, became the first Oba of Benin. Another son, Ajaka, became the first Alaafin of Oyo. Another, Osile, of Oke-Ona Egba. Ooni Lajamisan, another descendant of Oranmiyan is often said to have opened the modern Ife history. The four actual Ruling Houses{{cite news| work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)]]| url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/02/the-place-of-oranmiyan-in-the-history-of-ile-ife| title=The Place Of Oranmiyan In The History Of Ile – Ife|date=2016-02-22|accessdate=2016-04-20}} are named from Ooni Lafogido, Ooni Osinkola, Ooni Ogboru and Ooni Giesi. The first three were sons of Ooni Lajodogun, and the later a maternal grandson of Ogboru. The current Ooni is [[Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi]] Ojaja II (born October 17, 1974) ==Various authors have various lists== The primary sources for the history of the Yoruba are from oral tradition. Since there were not ceremonial recitations of the list of the Oonis (at burial or at crowning), there are in fact several oral traditions, that have generated an unusual number of different written transcriptions. In what follows, #nn is the index of the Ooni in the '''A list''' (see table, column '''LA'''). ===Books and research papers=== # Ojo Bada 1954{{cite book|author=Ojo, Bada of Shaki|year=1954|title=Iwe Itan Yoruba|publisher=Apa Kinni, Ibadan, 228 pages}} Cited from Ojuade & Obayemi, not read directly. quotes 15 names for the Oduduwa to Lajamisan period.{{cite journal|author=J Sina Ojuade|title=The issue of Oduduwa in Yoruba genesis: the myths and realities| journal=Transafrican Journal of History|volume=21|pp=139–158|year=1992|jstor=24520425}} (p.154){{cite journal|title=Ancient Ile-Ife: Another Cultural Historical Reinterpretation|author=Ade Obayemi|journal=Journal of the Historical Society of Nigeria|volume=9|number=4|date=June 1979|pp=151–185|jstor=41857206}} (p.158) See column '''5'''. # Chief Fabunmi 1975 quotes 7 names for the same period. See column '''6'''. Chief Fabunmi is known for his Historical notes.{{cite book|title=An Anthology of Historical Notes on Ife City|author=M. A. Fabunmi|publisher=J. See column '''8'''. # Eluyemi 1986 quotes 41 names from Oduduwa to nowadays. A. Adetunji 1999,{{cite book|title=The Glory of Yoruba Nation|author= Prince L. A. Adetunji|publisher=Lichfield Nigeria|year=1999|isbn=9789783049871|pages=128}} pages 70–77. The prince, from the Giesi family, was one of the contenders for the 2015 designation.{{cite web| work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)]]| url= http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/08/the-ooni-has-spiritual-and-physical-powers|title=The Ooni has spiritual and physical powers|date=2015-08-30|access-date=2016-04-21}} See column '''LA'''. #: Sources for the 50 items '''B list''' # Ologundu 2008,{{cite book |first= Dayo|last= Ologundudu |date= 2008|title=The cradle of Yoruba culture |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Vn8uAQAAIAAJ|publisher=Center for Spoken Words|isbn= 9780615220635|page=206}}{{cite book|title=Searchworks|work=Stanford|url=https://searchworks.stanford.edu/catalog/citation?id=10702157}} pages 58–59. Lists 48 names, that are the ''B list'', except from Obalufon Alayemore (#5) and Aworokolokin (#12). Moreover, Osinkola (#18) is at #25 (strange place)

See column '''LB'''. ===Web sources=== # Source 2015.http://ilfng.org/The-source.html, trustees= Chief Kemade Elugbaju, Hon. Rotimi Makinde, Dr. Akin Awofolaju, Dr. Ramon Adedoyin, Niyi Murele, Sen. Babajide Omoworare, Prince Adedamola Aderemi, Kehinde Awoyele, Prince Adeleke Ijiyode # Leadership.ng 2015.,{{cite web|url=http://leadership.ng/news/450530/ooni-of-ife-ademiluyi-family-set-to-produce-successor|title=Ooni Of Ife: Ademiluyi Family Set To Produce Successor|work=Leadership Newspaper|accessdate=July 30, 2015|date=2015-07-30}} 2015. No references are given. One typo: Ademiluyi Ajagun (1930-19800). # Ooni Ojaja II web site,{{cite web| url=http://www.ooniojajaii.com/history-pastooni.html|title=Past Ooni of Ife|access-date=2016-04-21}} 2016 quotes 51 names. Same as '''list B''', differs only by the diacritics. No references are given. This list was already in use before 2015. ===Influence on king making=== The filling of the stool of a deceased Ooni of Ife is not a simple local affair as it may seem but has national ramifications. Since Ife is regarded as the cradle of the Yoruba, this town has always been the leading religious center of the Yoruba people. But other roles are also involved.{{cite web|url= http://www.ancient-origins.net/history-famous-people/rulers-ife-traditional-and-adaptive-roles-ooni-004055?nopaging=1|date=2015-10-03|title=The Rulers of Ife: The Traditional and Adaptive Roles of the Ooni|work=Ancient Origins}} Especially, the Ooni of Ife is often presented as the highest ranked Oba or, even more, as the natural chairman of the Council of Yoruban Chiefs.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=LtAkDl3OrQgC|title=Nigerian Chiefs: Traditional Power in Modern Politics, 1890s-1990s|series=Rochester studies in African history and the diaspora|author=Olufemi Vaughan|publisher=University Rochester Press|year=2006|isbn=9781580462495|p=168}} The rules to fill a vacant stool are the Chiefs Law Cap 25 Laws of Osun State (modified 2002).{{cite web|title=Erring on the law to fill Ooni stool|author=Dr. Abiola Sanni|work=Bar Alpha (Nigeria)|url=https://baralpha.com/2015/09/22/erring-on-the-law-to-fill-ooni-stool-1|access-date=2016-04-21}} And the Declaration made in 1980 by the traditional Chiefs under Section 4(2) of this Chief Law. In 1957, the former Declaration recognised four ruling houses and established the following order of rotation: # The Oshinkola House, Iremo (present) [as of 1957] # The Giesi House, More # The Ogboru House, Ilare #The Lafogido House, Okerewe In 1977, references to locations in Ife were suppressed. And the January 1980 Declaration confirmed everything just before the death of Adesoji Aderemi. These families are tagged in column '''desc''', as sourced from Vanguard{{cite news|work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)]]|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/10/the-ooni-stool-yoruba-nation-how-the-geisi-family-joined-the-ruling-class|date=2015-10-31|accessdate=2016-04-26|title=How Giesi Family Joined the Ruling Class}} for Lafog, Osink, Ogbor, Giesi. And Newz{{cite web|url=http://newzloaded.com/names-of-ife-king-ooni-from-oduduwa-ascension|title=Names of Ife Ooni, from Oduduwa ascension }} for the rest. (Both sources don't give their own sources). In 2015, it was the turn of the Giesi Family, as confirmed by the Ife kingmakers.{{cite web|title=Ife kingmakers narrow selection of Ooni to Giesi Family|work=Nigerian Tribune |url=http://tribuneonlineng.com/ife-kingmakers-narrow-selection-ooni-giesi-family|date=2015-09-14|accessdate=2016-04-21}} Nevertheless: * Olakunle Aderemi (leader of Osinkola) said that, despite having produced Adesoji Aderemi (1930-1980), Osinkola house deserved to produce the new King because the family produced the least number of the Ooni among the four ruling houses. Ife Chieftaincy Declaration of 1980 technically throws open the contest for filling the stool of Ooni, he added.{{cite web|url=http://www.thescoopng.com/new-ooni-as-expected-ruling-houses-have-already-started-fighting|accessdate=2016-04-21|title=New Ooni: As expected, ruling houses have already started fighting|date=2015-08-27|work=The Scoop (Nigeria)}} * The Lafogido house went to court, describing the Chieftaincy Declaration as unfair. Lafogido house had been constantly marginalized in chieftaincy reviews in Ife since 1957 they said. 14 Oonis have been enthroned from Lajodogun and only 8 from Lafogido ruling house they added.{{cite news| url= http://www.thescoopng.com/ife-kingmakers-announce-that-giesi-would-produce-next-ooni-but-one-other-family-is-heading-to-court|title= Ife kingmakers announce that Giesi would produce next Ooni; but one other family is heading to court|date=2015-09-14|accessdate=2016-04-21|work=The Scoop (Nigeria)}} * Adetowo Aderemi (of Osinkola) got even further, faulting the 1957 and 1980 Ife Traditional Council Declarations, describing them as a fraud. That they are against the customary law of succession of the Ife people, he said. He also faulted the inclusion of Giesi Ruling House among eligible royal families to fill the stool of Ooni, saying that Giesi was only invited to complete the term of Ogboru, not being from the male lineage with right to the stool as the grandson of Ogboru.{{cite web|title=New Ooni: Bickering gets worse as Osinkola Ruling House distances self from rotation of crown|url=http://www.thescoopng.com/new-ooni-bickering-gets-worse-as-osinkola-ruling-house-distances-self-from-rotation-of-crown|date=2015-09-06|accessdate=2016-04-21}} Finally, [[Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi]], from the Giesi house, was elected October 26, 2015.{{cite web|work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)]]|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/10/profile-of-ogunwusi-named-ooni-elect|date=2015-10-27|accessdate=2016-04-21|title=Profile of Ogunwusi Ooni-elect}} == Avoiding original research when consolidating == === Consolidation at the price of the diacritics === The Yoruba language is written using the [[Pan-Nigerian alphabet]].
